bibl.title: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, December 12, 1924

div1.p: Fisher discusses the recent malaria conference. He offers his opinion on the Southern Power Company's plan to impound water.

div1.head: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, December 12, 1924
div1.opener:
JAMES A. HAYNE, M.D.
Secretary and State Health Officer
L. M. FISHER
Associate Sanitary Engineer
U. S. Public Health Service
In Charge Malaria Co-operative Work
State Board of Health
of South Carolina
DIVISION MALARIA CO-OPERATIVE WORK
Columbia
Dec. 12, 1924.
Malaria
Fisher
Dr. H. R. Carter
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
The Maddox cast at Union was continued until the February
term of court and will probably be continued until May.

We had a very instructive meeting at New Orleans. The re-
sults Coogle got with creosote were not verified by the ex-
periments that Kmop and Theodore Hayne made. There was some
discussion as to whether or not other species than Quadri-
maculatus conveyed malaria in nature. Dr. Darling advocates
controlling only the breeding places producing Quadrimaculatus.
This aroused considerable discussion. From a practical stand-
point it is not advisable to leave the other breeding places
uncontrolled, because the public will not appropriate money
to control only one species of mosquitoes. Besides that, I
do not think Darling has completely established his case.

Our observations at Chester came in for considerable criticism.
During the past summer I searched the daylight roosting
places around Chester, at monthly intervals during the season,
and found only Punctipennis except near one railroad borrow pit,
I found one Crucians.

Dr. L. L. Williams, Jr., got away with murder. He said
malaria in Virginia is caused only by Quadrimaculatus. Quad-
rimaculatus breed only in ponds. Breeding in ponds can be
controlled by fluctuating the water level, therefore, malaria
can be eliminated in Virginia by fluctuating water levels in
ponds. Some of the ponds around the army and navy base at
Norfolk, and near pig pondpoints are saucer shaped depressions that
-2-
had no outlet until we dug ditches. Artificial fluctuation
of the water surface was out of the question. Fluctuation will
also not control the breeding in seepage areas where quads and
crucians breed at times. It is of course an important fact that
quadrimaculatus convey more malaria than the other species, and
our efforts should be directed principally but not exclussively
against them.

Dr. Griffiths' methods of distributing oil on impounded waters
is a valuable contribution to our knowledge of control methods.

I think in a year or so we will have some new mosquito cases
against the Southern Power Company. They are planning to raise
the Wateree Pond six feet, and are building a much larger dam
on the Catawba River near Rock Hill. I fear that in spite of
all precautions there will be an increase in malaria at these
ponds.

I inquired about the letter to Theodore Hayne, and was advised
that he had received it. I think he has written to you to that
effect.

I hope you are getting along well and are able to keep up your
work on yellow fever. We all missed you very much at the Con-
ference. Please remember me to Miss Laura.
With the season's best wishes and kindest regards,
div1.closer: Yours very truly, L. M. Fisher.
